awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation's (NSF) Directorate for Computer and Information Science and
Engineering (CISE) is committed to broadening the participation of underrepresented populations in
computing and closely-related disciplines. Indeed, CISE strongly encourages meaningful actions that
address the longstanding underrepresentation of various populations including women, minorities
(African Americans/Blacks, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians,
Native Pacific Islanders, and persons from economically disadvantaged backgrounds), and persons with
disabilities, in the computing field.

Unfortunately, only a few (or no) historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) have participated in proposal submission/awardees to broadening participation in computing since 2012. Even though there are newer NSF programs, such as Computing Education for 21st Century (CE21) along with Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics-Computing (STEM-C) Partnerships, there are still few proposals submitted by and awarded to HBCUs.

This workshop will enable HBCU computer science/computing faculty to collaborate and address the needs associated with broadening participation and create cross-institutional strategies to increase research outcomes. Workshop participants will engage in post-workshop meetings at CS conferences and virtually to increase the level of accountability associated with NSF grantsmanship.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Department of Computer Science at Hampton University hosted a series of workshops for HBCU Computer Science faculty partners to provide an open discussion on the merits and advantages of submitting research proposals individually and collectively to the CISE Program at NSF. We came together collectively as HBCUs to seek solutions that will consequently help increase the number of HBCU proposal submissions, resulting in funding projects where HBCUs serve as the lead Institutions, within NSF CISE BPC programs.

1) The First HBCU Computer Science Faculty Workshop, May 31-June 1, 2019.  There were 14 HBCUs with a total of 27 faculty attended.

2) The 2nd HBCU Computer Science Faculty Workshop, January 31-February 1, 2020. There were 13 HBCUs with a total of 25 faculty attended.

3) The 2020 HBCU Ideas Workshops (Phase I, organized by QEM in partnership with NSF and ASEE) - November 30 and December 2, 2020.   There were 18 HBCUs with a total of 38 HBCU faculty attended. We organized the participants into 4 Research infinitive Groups: Fairness in AI, Computational Biology – Genomics, Quantum Computing, and Cybersecurity.

4) The 2021 NSF CISE Proposal Development Workshop for Researchers at Minority-Serving Institutions (Phase II, organized by ASEE): February 16, February 19, February 26, March 5, and March 12, 2021.  The total number of HBCU participants: 45 HBCU participants (out of approximately 144 total participants); The total number of HBCU institutions: 22 universities.  Of those participants, 23 faculty from 11 HBCUs have attended all 4 workshops. 

5) The HBCU CS Faculty Workshop in Conjunction with the 2022 ADMI Symposium: March 24, 2022 (Virtual). The total number of 20 faculty from 11 HBCUs.

6) The Final HBCU CS Faculty Workshop, May 23-24, 2022 (Virtual), The total number of HBCU faculty participants was 18 from  10 HBCUs.  We organized the participants into 3 core groups: Computer Science Education, Data Science, and Natural Language Processing in Cybersecurity.  Each team continues its meetings and plans on submitting at least one proposal to NSF. 

 

Funded NSF Awards as a result of these workshops:

1) Collaborative Research: CISE-MSI: RPEP: SaTC: HBCU Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (AI-CyS) Research Partnership   (Total of $1.3M across all collaborators: Hampton University (Lead Institute), Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University, Winston-Salem State University, University of the District of Columbia, Norfolk State University, Mississippi Valley State University, and Howard University.

2) Increasing Career Competencies in Computer Networking Courses using Simulation, Hands-On Learning, and Project-Based Learning Within a Cognitive Apprenticeship Framework.  (Total of $298K, Hampton University)

 

Additional proposals have been submitted.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Jean Muhammad

1) The First HBCU Computer Science Faculty Workshop, May 31-June 1, 2019.  There were 14 HBCUs with a total of 27 faculty attended.

We organized the participants into 3 core groups: Computer Science Education, Data Science, and Natural Language Processing in Cybersecurity.  Each team continues its meetings and plans on submitting at least one proposal to NSF.
